aurora Package¶

ap_monitor Module¶

The AP Monitor module tracks AP status and processes received messages.

class aurora.ap_monitor.APMonitor(dispatcher, aurora_db, host, username, password)[source]¶

Bases: object

Handles AMQP response messages from access points.

SLEEP_TIME = 45¶

Sets up and configures the environment required for message passing using AMQP.

  • aurora_db (aurora.aurora_db.AuroraDB) –

  • username (str) – RabbitMQ username

_build_slice_id_ssid_map(config)[source]¶

Called from within process_response, this method will find the ap_slice_id’s on an access point from its returned config, and will determine their associated SSID.

Parameters:config (dict) – Configuration returned from access point
Return type:dict
_close_poller_thread(ap_name, unique_id)[source]¶

Stops a single AP poller thread by ap_name.

_make_queue_daemon()[source]¶

Creates a queue daemon which watches for set_status calls and adds them to a FIFO queue. This ensures the _set_status method does not get executed twice at the same time, which can cause the manager to place slices in a confused state.

_set_status(cmd_category, *args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Sets the status of the associated request in the database based on the previous status, i.e. pending -> active if create slice, deleting -> deleted if deleting a slice, etc. If the ap_up variable is false, the access point is considered to be offline and in an unknown state, so *all* slices are marked as such (down, failed, etc.).

Parameters:
  • cmd_category – Determines which set_status method should run, can be one of [None, "AP reset", "slice_stats"]
  • args – Arguments
  • kwargs – Keyword Arguments

poll_AP(ap_name, stop_event=None)[source]¶

Poller thread target: sends the access point a message in a regular interval. Stopped when stop_event is set, typically when an access point goes offline.

Parameters:
  • ap_name (str) – Name of the access point
  • stop_event (threading.Event) –
process_response(channel, method, props, body)[source]¶

Processes messages received from active access points.

The responses are checked against previously sent message to see if any correlation IDs match. If yes, the response is displayed along with the request originally sent, and is then parsed to determine what the original message was. The databases are updated accordingly.

Parameters:
  • channel (pika.channel.Channel) –
  • method (pika.frame.Method.method) –
  • props (pika.frame.Header.properties) –
  • body (str) –
recreate_slices(ap, slice_list)[source]¶

Recreats the slices on their access point.

This is different than restarting a slice, because the configuration is assumed to already exist on the AP in question.

Parameters:
  • ap (str) – Name of the access point
  • slice_list (list) – List of slices to recreate

Reset the access point. If there are serious issues, however, a restart may be required.

Parameters:ap (str) –

Restart the access point, telling the OS to reboot.

Parameters:ap (str) –

start_poller(ap_name)[source]¶

Starts a poller to track the status of an access point.

Parameters:ap_name (str) – Name of the access point
stop()[source]¶

Stops all threads created by AP Monitor.

timeout(ap_slice_id, ap_name, message_uuid=None)[source]¶

This code will execute when a response is not received for the command associated with the unique_id after a certain time period. It modifies the database to reflect the current status of the AP.

A timeout is serious: it is likely that the AP’s OS has crashed, or at least aurora is no longer running.

Parameters:
  • ap_slice_id (str) –
  • ap_name (str) –
  • message_uuid (str) –
update_records(message)[source]¶

Update the traffic information of ap_slice.

Parameters:message (dict) – Message containing reported slice stats

ap_slice_update_time_stats(ap_slice_id=None, ap_name=None, ap_down=False)[source]¶

Records the current time and calculates current and cumulative uptime for a slice on an access point.

If the slice ID is the only parameter given, only that slice is updated. Otherwise, all the slices on the access point in question will be updated.

Note

This method does not check the status of the slices it is passed. You must make sure they are candidates for metering before calling this method.

Parameters:
  • ap_slice_id (str) – ID of the slice to update
  • ap_name (str) – Name of the access point where the slice resides
  • ap_down (bool) – Status of the AP in question

ap_status_unknown(ap_name=None)[source]¶

Sets the status of an access point to ‘UNKNOWN’. This will occur when the manager has shut down and is no longer polling the APs, though they could still be active.

Parameters:ap_name (str) –
ap_status_up(ap_name=None)[source]¶

Sets the status of an access point to ‘UP’.

Parameters:ap_name (str) –
Raises :NoAPNameGivenException
ap_syn_clean_deleting_status(ap_name)[source]¶

Cleans up slice statuses for slices deleted while an AP is offline.

Invoked when manager receives a SYN message from an access point indicating it is connecting. Access points which connect to manager will not restart slices that are marked as ‘DELETING’, therefore we should change their status to ‘DELETED’ to confirm they no longer exist.

Parameters:ap_name (str) –

cls_logger Module¶

LOGGER importer module for class use.

class aurora.cls_logger.CustomFormatter(fmt=None, datefmt=None)[source]¶

Bases: logging.Formatter

Extends logging.Formatter class with a custom formatting method.

Usage:

import logging
from aurora import cls_logger
class A():
    def __init__(self):
        self.LOGGER = cls_logger.get_cls_logger(self)

    def hello_world(self):
        # String substitutions work
        self.LOGGER.info("%s World!", "Hello")

def main():
    cls_logger.set_up_root_logger(level=logging.INFO)
    a = A()
    a.hello_world()
    a.LOGGER.warn("This works too.")
format(record)[source]¶

Formats the logged message to include a tag with the calling module and class name with the tag length no longer than specified self.max_width_limit. Also tracks which classes are calling the format function, if it is a new class the class name is added to class_loggers list.:

[module_name----ClassName] Logged Message
Parameters:record (LogRecord) – LogRecord with log information
Return type:str
max_width = 0¶
max_width_limit = 30¶
normalize(width_map)[source]¶

Normalizes a given mapping of module and class name lengths, zeroing values above self.max_width_limit.

Parameters:width_map (list) – List containing lengths of logger name mistrings
Return type:list
aurora.cls_logger.get_cls_logger(cls)[source]¶

Assign a logger to a class only if no prior logger has been assigned

Parameters:cls (class) – Class to which LOGGER should be assigned
Return type:logging.Logger
aurora.cls_logger.set_up_root_logger(level=None)[source]¶

Sets up the root logger with a handler created by setup_handler() method. Sets root logging level to provided level arg, defaults is WARN

Parameters:level (int – logging.level) – Desired level of logging, specified in logging module

dispatcher Module¶

The dispatcher module handles AMQP connection setup and transmission of messages.

class aurora.dispatcher.Dispatcher(host, username, password, mysql_username, mysql_password, aurora_db, queue='')[source]¶

Bases: object

The Dispatcher class sets up a connection to a RabbitMQ server and configures a reply queue for access points to direct messages to. It also provides a method for sending a configuration message to a specific access point.

RESTART_TIMEOUT = 30¶
SPLIT_SECOND = 1¶
TIMEOUT = 45¶
WAIT_TIME_INTERVAL = 0.25¶
WAIT_TO_DISPATCH_TIMEOUT = 5¶
__init__(host, username, password, mysql_username, mysql_password, aurora_db, queue='')[source]¶

Configures a dispatcher instance in order to set up connections, channels, and queues.

_get_uuid_for_ap_syn(ap_syn)[source]¶

A factory for finding all messages by UUID sent to the access point name ap_syn.

Parameters:ap_syn (str) – Name of the access point for which messages should be found.
Yields :List of message UUIDs for messages sent to AP
_pika_monitor_loop(stop_event=None)[source]¶

Target for pika monitor thread.

Runs a continuous loop until stop_event is set, testing whether pika connection is active and a channel exists. If something has gone wrong, _restart_connection() is called.

Parameters:stop_event (threading.Event) –
_restart_connection()[source]¶

A method to stop and start a connection, waiting for some timeout for a connection to be established and a channel to be created.

Once a connection and channel have been set up, this method notifies APs (sends ‘SYN’ message).

_send_manager_up_status()[source]¶

Dispatches a ‘SYN’ message to all known access points. If the access points respond, they are marked as ‘UP’, otherwise, after some timeout, they will be marked as ‘DOWN’.

_start_connection()[source]¶

Step 1: Entry point for starting a new AMQP connetion.

Connects to RabbitMQ server and provides a callback to execute once the connection is established. Begins an IOLoop to watch for message events.

_start_pika_channel_open_monitor()[source]¶

Creates a thread which will monitor the pika connection.

The thread is stoppable, and will run an endless loop until its stop_event is set.

_stop_all_request_sent_timers()[source]¶

Empties the list tracking sent requests, and cancels all associated timers.

_stop_connection()[source]¶

Runs cleanup to stop the dispatcher’s connection with RabbitMQ.

Stops the poller threads created in AP Monitor so they will not try and send a message while the connection is down. Also stops the timers associated with sent messages - if we cannot receive a reply it doesn’t make sense to wait for one.

_stop_pika_channel_open_monitor()[source]¶

Stops the pika monitor thread.

channel_open(new_channel)[source]¶

Step 3: Store the returned channel and request a reply queue to which access points can send their messages.

Parameters:new_channel (pika.channel.Channel) –
consume_on_queue(queue)¶

Step 5: Direct all incoming messages to be handled by set_response_callback().

Check whether we were restarting a connection - if so, set the restarting flag to false - the connection is now active. In the case it isn’t being restarted, send let access points know manager has successfully set up a connection, channel, and reply queue (send manager ‘SYN’ message).

Also launch a thread to monitor the status of the AMQP connection.

Parameters:queue (str) – The queue to which access points will respond
dispatch(config, ap, unique_id=None)[source]¶

Send data to the specified queue.

Some commands will provide a unique_id to use, such as ap_slice_create() – the ap_slice_id will typically be used. In the case that none is provided, one will be generated. For both cases, the unique_id is prepended by the access point name, in order to identify which messages have been sent to which APs.

Some issues occur if this method is called many times in parallel for the same AP, thus a access-point dependent lock is used. Everything should be OK when dispatching in parallel to many different APs.

Note

This issue also happens when sending and receiving for the same AP in parallel, thus when the messages are received by the callable in self.response_callback, this lock should be checked:

if ap_name in Dispatcher.lock:
    LOGGER.info("Locked for %s, waiting...", ap_name)
    while ap_name in Dispatcher.lock:
        time.sleep(0.1)

Note

The caller is expected to set SQL database properties such as status.

Parameters:
  • config (dict) – Slice configuration
  • ap (str) – Access point on which slice should be created
  • unique_id (str) – Unique ID to be assigned as the AMQP correlation ID
Raises :

DispatchLockedForAPTimeout

MessageSendAttemptWhileClosing

DispatchWaitForOpenChannelTimeout

KeyboardInterrupt
dispatch_count = 0¶
get_open_channel()[source]¶

Returns self.channel if it is open, otherwise returns None.

have_request(correlation_id)[source]¶

Checks whether a request for correlation_id was previously sent. If it was, returns a tuple containing a bool for success and the request, if exists, else None.

Parameters:correlation_id (str) – Correlation ID to check
Returns:tuple – Index 0 is true if request exists, index 1 contains the request or None.
ioloop_thread_start_target()[source]¶

A target method for a thread in which pika’s IOLoop can run. Since some exceptions can happen in the IOLoop thread, catch them if they occur and restart the connection to start with a clean slate.

lock = []¶
on_connected(connection)[source]¶

Step 2: Requests a new channel and provides a callback which will execute once a channel has been assigned.

Parameters:connection (pika.adapters.select_connection.SelectConnection) –
on_queue_declared(frame)[source]¶

Step 4: Store the returned reply queue and track it for future reference by access points in AP provision database.

Parameters:frame (pika.frame.Method) –
remove_request(message_uuid=None, ap_syn=None)[source]¶

Removes a request from the requests sent list and cancels the associated timer. If ap_syn is set, all requests for that AP are removed and their timers cancelled – at this point it is known that the AP will not respond to any of the previously issued messages.

Parameters:
  • message_uuid (str) – UUID of the request to remove
  • ap_syn (str) – Name of the AP from which Manager received a syn message
set_close_pollers_callback(close_pollers_callback)[source]¶

Stores a method which will close all AP pollers (see close_all_poller_threads) in case the connection dies and needs to be restarted.

Parameters:close_pollers_callback (callable) –
set_response_callback(response_callback)[source]¶

Stores a method which will be executed upon receipt of a message on an incoming queue.

Parameters:response_callback (callable) –
set_timeout_callback(timeout_callback)[source]¶

Stores a callback function which will be called if a sent message does not receive a correlated reply within a set timeout.

Parameters:timeout_callback (callable) –

External interface for starting a new AMQP connection.

status_closing = False¶
stop()[source]¶

External interface for stopping the dispatcher. This will cleanly let RabbitMQ know we’re closing up, and will also stop the pika channel monitor thread.

exc Module¶

Module containing exceptions for use in Aurora Manager.

exception aurora.exc.APSliceAlreadyInWnetException(message=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: aurora.exc.AuroraException

exception aurora.exc.AuroraException(message=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: exceptions.Exception

Base class for exceptions in Aurora. Inherit it and define info to use it.

An inherited class should include an overridden message, which can contain key word arguments such as %(kw)s. These will be substituted upon raising your exception:

raise MyAuroraException(kw="my keyword string")

manager Module¶

The manager module houses the bulk of the logic required to process commands received from a client.

class aurora.manager.Manager[source]¶

Bases: object

High level manager class for handling client requests.

Every client command has an associated handler in this Manager class. Each handler is structured to take an argument dictionary, as well as tenant_id, project_id, and user_id. They should all return a dictionary with a boolean ‘successful’ to notify client if the query was handled without error, as well as a message with additional information.

__init__()[source]¶

Sets up the environment which Manager will use to handle specific tasks.

Required components include a database handler, message dispatcher (AMQP), and AP Monitor to track access point status information.

Additionally, an HTTP server is set up to provision initial AP configurations.

ap_add(args, tenant_id, user_id, project_id)[source]¶

Adds an AP to the SQL database and dispatches a SYN message.

Return type:dict
ap_add_tag(args, tenant_id, user_id, project_id)[source]¶

location=mcgill 
status=UP 
num_radio_free=1
Parameters:args (str) –
Return type:list

Returns a list to the client with nicely printed information about the available access points.

Some options are available:

-i Additional information
Return type:dict
ap_reset(args, tenant_id, user_id, project_id)[source]¶

Resets an access point.

Note

This results in all the slices on the access point being removed – they can then be restarted using ap-slice-restart.

Return type:dict
ap_show(args, tenant_id, user_id, project_id)[source]¶

Returns more detailed information about an access point to the client.

Return type:dict
ap_slice_add_tag(args, tenant_id, user_id, project_id)[source]¶

Adds a tag to a slice in the database.

Return type:dict
ap_slice_create(args, tenant_id, user_id, project_id)[source]¶

Configures and dispatches the message required to create a slice on an access point.

The configuration can be passed to this function by a JSON file, which will then be validated using a slice plugin. The validated configuration will the be stored in a configuration database, in case it is required in the future.

Some slice data is writen to the SQL database to track its history and associated SSID, owner, and project.

The --hint option should give the user some help in choosing a good access point on which he can create his slice.

Return type:dict
ap_slice_delete(args, tenant_id, user_id, project_id)[source]¶

Deletes a slice from an access point.

The associated slice configuration is also removed from the JSON configuration database. The slice is marked as ‘DELETED’ in the ap_slice SQL table.

Return type:dict
ap_slice_filter(arg_filter, tenant_id)[source]¶

A helper method for finding wireless slices based on their SQL entries. Example arg_filter strings:

location=mcgill 
status=ACTIVE
ap_slice_ssid=MySSID
Parameters:
  • args (str) –
  • tenant_id (str) –
Return type:

list
ap_slice_list(args, tenant_id, user_id, project_id)[source]¶

Returns a nicely printed table of slices owned by a tenant.

Some options are available:

-i Additional information
-a Include deleted slices
Return type:dict
ap_slice_modify(args, tenant_id, user_id, project_id)[source]¶

This method will take parameters from the user and modify one or more given slices. The slices can be passed either by ap_slice_id or by a filter argument.

Valid choices for the command line include:

--interface <tag:endpoint>
 Capsulator configuration
--encrypt <type:key>
 Encryption for slice
--ssid <ap> New SSID for slice
--br <controller>
 Bridge controller address
--file <FILE> JSON config file

An abbreviated json with the modifications is generated. As each section requires a ‘name’ argument on the agent side, the name of the interface/ssid is found from the configuration database.

Return type:dict
ap_slice_move(args, tenant_id, user_id, project_id)[source]¶

Moves a slice from once access point to another.

The configuration for the slice must not be given, and will be fetched from the configuration database by slice ID and tenant ID. No special handover methods are implemented, and all wireless clients connected to the slice will have to reassociate with the new access point.

Return type:dict
ap_slice_remove_tag(args, tenant_id, user_id, project_id)[source]¶

Removes a tag from a slice in the database.

Return type:dict
ap_slice_restart(args, tenant_id, user_id, project_id)[source]¶

Restarts a slice on an access point.

The configuration should be stored in the JSON configuration database kept by Manager - it is this configuration that is dispatched to the access point.

Return type:dict
ap_slice_show(args, tenant_id, user_id, project_id)[source]¶

Shows more detailed information about a specific slice.

Return type:dict
ap_slice_sync_config(args, tenant_id, user_id, project_id)[source]¶

Queries the access point for a slice and updates the JSON configuration database associated with that slice based on the received data.

This ensures that the configuration database and the access point store the same information about slices.

Return type:dict
configuration_generation(args, tenant_id, user_id, project_id)¶

Return type:dict
wnet_update_ssid(args, tenant_id, user_id, project_id)[source]¶

Updates the SSID of slices within a wnet.

SSIDs must be unique on each access point, thus the slices contained within a wnet must all be on different access points. Additionally, no access point may already be hosting an existing slice with the new ssid.

Return type:dict

manager_http_server Module¶

Simple Manager HTTP Server for communicating JSON configuration files between Aurora Manager and Client.

A possible entry point for starting manager is main().

class aurora.manager_http_server.ManagerServer(server_address, RequestHandlerClass, bind_and_activate=True)[source]¶

Bases: BaseHTTPServer.HTTPServer

Builds upon BaseHTTPServer.HTTPServer.

Includes a logger, instantiates a aurora.manager.Manager instance and stores a static reference for it in self.RequestHandlerClass. Also handles cleanup on exit.

serve_forever()[source]¶

Run to start the ManagerServer.

server_close()[source]¶

Run to close the ManagerServer.

class aurora.manager_http_server.NewConnectionHandler(*args)[source]¶

Bases: BaseHTTPServer.BaseHTTPRequestHandler

Handles client HTTP requests.

A new NewConnectionHandler is created for every incoming connection received by ManagerServer. The handler defines the behavior upon receipt of a GET or POST HTTP message. The communication structure is such that a client will first post a message containing a configuration JSON which be passed to aurora.manager.Manager, and will then follow up with a GET request for feedback about execution of the issued command.

Only one instance of aurora.manager.Manager will be created, and a handle for this instance is stored in NewConnectionHandler.MANAGER.

MANAGER = None¶
__init__(*args)[source]¶

Verifies an aurora.manager.Manager instance exists to handle client requests.

Parameters:args (args) – Arguments to set up BaseHTTPServer.BaseHTTPRequestHandler
do_GET()[source]¶

Handles a GET request.

Sends a 200-OK response with the data from the response file.

do_POST()[source]¶

Handles a POST request.

Parses some aspects of the request to determine what function is being requested, as well as which tenant, project, and user the request belongs to. Passes the command to aurora.manager.Manager.parseargs(), and stores the returned response. This response will later be relayed back to the client by a client GET request.

sendPage(type, body)[source]¶

Sends a page to a client. Unused at the moment.

Parameters:
  • type (str) – Type of data being sent ex. 'application/json'
  • body – Data to send to client.
server_version = 'Aurora/0.2'¶
aurora.manager_http_server.main()[source]¶

An entry point for launching Aurora Manager.

Sets up root-level logger. Assigns a the request handler class. Starts the HTTP server ManagerServer. Performs some basic error handling and outputs tracebacks.

The logging level can be specified from command line arguments.

See also

aurora.shell

shell Module¶

Intended entry point for Aurora Manager.

Usage:

$ python shell.py <DEBUG|INFO|WARNING|ERROR|CRITICAL>

or:

>>> import sys
>>> sys.path.append('/path/to/aurora/package/dir')
>>> from aurora.shell import main
>>> main()

shell_local Module¶

Warning

Out of date and unused! Use at own risk.

Command-line interface to the Aurora API Uses a JSON file for commands:

Format:[
         {
          optional:[[oarg1, {attributes}],[oarg2, {attributes}]...], 
          positional:[[parg1, {attributes}], [parg2, {attributes}]...], 
          subargument:[[subarg1, {attributes}, [[osarg1, {attributes}], [osarg2, {attributes}]]], [subarg2, {attributes}]...]
         }
       ]

slice_json_generator Module¶

Warning

Out of date and unused! Use at own risk.

Module for generating a JSON configuration. To be compatible with Aurora Manager v0.2 and later, follow the structure of this functional JSON configuration:

{
    "VirtualWIFI": [
        {
            "flavor" : "wifi_radio",
            "attributes" : 
                {
                    "name" : "radio0",
                    "channel" : "1",
                    "txpower" : "20",
                    "disabled" : "0",
                    "country" : "CA",
                    "hwmode" : "abg"   
                }
        },
        {
            "flavor" : "wifi_bss",
            "attributes" : 
                {
                    "name" : "NetworkSSID",
                    "radio" : "radio0",
                    "if_name" : "wlan0",
                    "encryption_type":"wep-open",
                    "key":"00000"
                }
        }
    ], 
    "VirtualBridges": [
        {
            "flavor":"linux_bridge",
            "attributes":   
                {
                    "name":"linux-br",
                    "interfaces":
                        ["vwlan0","tun0"],
                    "bridge_settings":{},
                    "port_settings":{}
                }
        }
    ], 
    "VirtualInterfaces": [
        {
            "flavor":"capsulator",
            "attributes": 
                {
                    "attach_to":"eth0",
                    "name":"tun0",
                    "forward_to":"10.0.0.1",
                    "tunnel_tag":"auto",
                    "is_virtual":true
                }
        },
        {
            "flavor":"veth",
            "attributes": 
                {
                    "attach_to":"wlan0",
                    "name":"vwlan0",
                    "mac":"00:00:00:00:00:01"
                }
        }
    ]
}

stop_thread Module¶

Module containing threads which can run a continuous loop until a stop event is thrown. Thread target code must have a keyword argument for stop_event and must check it periodically eg.:

import time
from aurora.stop_thread import *

def my_target(my_arg, stop_event=None):
    i = 0
    print "Your arg: %s" % my_arg
    while True:
        if stop_event.is_set():
            break
        print "Iteration %s." % i 
        i += 1
        time.sleep(1)

t = StoppableThread(target=my_target, args=("This is some arg",))
t.start()
time.sleep(3.5)
t.stop()
t.join()
class aurora.stop_thread.StoppableThread(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: threading.Thread

Thread class with a stop method to any started threads which have target callable executing a continuous loop.

__init__(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Sets up kwargs for stoppable thread.

add_stop_argument(kwargs)[source]¶

Adds the 'stop_event' argument to the keyword args passed to the thread target.

Parameters:kwargs (dict) – Keyword arguments to pass to target
Returns:dict – Keyword arguments including 'stop_event'
stop()[source]¶

Sets the stop event flag

stopped()[source]¶

Check whether a thread has been stopped.

Bases: aurora.stop_thread.StoppableThread
